Elliotte Harold wrote:
> Cedric Beust wrote:
> 
>  > In JUnit, you have four ways to initialize / tear down your test, and 
> they
>  > are *all* equivalent:
>  >
>  > - At the beginning and end of each test method
>  > - In setUp()/tearDown()
>  > - In the constructor
>  > - At the field declaration level
>  >
>  > I find that confusing as hell, so I *strongly* recommend to use
>  > setUp/tearDown at the exclusion of everything else.  Again, the idea 
> is to
>  > make the intent obvious.
> 
> I prefer the opposite. Use anything except setUp/tearDown. Constructors,
> field initializers, and local variables are all standard parts of Java
> that every competent Java programmer immediately understands.
> setUp()/tearDown() is the odd one out. It is a special thing that only
> works in JUnit. Since it doesn't do anything the other three don't, why
> reinvent the wheel?

...because as soon as they try to do the same thing on another xUnit 
platform, notably NUnit, they will find only [SetUp] and [TearDown] do 
what they expected.

Incidentally, assuming you need to tear down fixture objects -- and 
admittedly it's rare for me -- if you don't use tearDown(), then how do 
you do it? (Or is it the case for you as for me that it just doesn't 
come up much?)
--
